author: Megan Backhouse
title: Why bromeliads are big right now
text:
Bromeliads have become popular with landscape architects. Picture: Isabella Lettini Photo: Isabella Lettini 
The current trend for using Tillandsia  or air plants as "living sculpture" will be one of the points of discussion in a talk on bromeliads by past president of the Bromeliad Society Bryan Paten at Burnley Gardens (500 Yarra Boulevard, Richmond) on October 13.
Called Bromeliads â€“ fashionable designer plants or tried-and-true oldies , the lecture is hosted by Friends of Burnley Gardens, at 7pm for 7.30pm start, costing $15 or $5 for members. Bookings are essential by email to a.smith@unimelb.edu.au or phone 9035 6861.
Open to admire Celia Rosser's artworks of banksias are the subject of a talk on October 7. 
Espaliering, composting and flora chosen to attract fauna are all features of an Eltham garden where  Sustainable Gardening Australia will be conducting three tours tomorrow. The garden is at 3 Moola Place, Eltham, and the tours cost $15. Go to sgaonline.org.au for more information.
Advertisement The cottage garden around an 1850s bluestone farmhouse that was part of the German settlement of Westgarthtown, is open today and tomorrow from 10am to 4.30pm, with entry by gold-coin donation. Zibell's Farmhouse Garden is at 100 Gardenia Road, Thomastown.   See opengardensvictoria.org.au for more information.
The Upper Yarra Valley Garden Club has its annual open gardens weekend today and tomorrow, from 10am to last entry at 4.30pm. There will be  five gardens on show, from Seville to the Warburton area. There will be signs for the gardens along the Warburton Highway.  Entry passes are $5 a garden, or $20 for all five and are available for sale at all gardens.
Behind the scenes of banksias Carolyn Landon, who recently wrote a book on botanical artist Celia Rosser, will speak about Rosser and the Monash Banksia Project on Wednesday, October 7, at Mueller Hall, National Herbarium, Birdwood Avenue, Melbourne.
The talk, presented by the Friends of the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne, is at 6pm for 6.30pm, $25 or $20 for friends and $10 for students. Bookings are essential, either online at rbgfriendsmelbourne.org or by phone, 9650 6398.
